node.title: Study links bad air with obesity among children
node.description: The study advises urgent action to control air pollution in cities like Delhi.

node.title: Raab visits Pakistan to help Afghan refugee effort
node.description: The foreign secretary's regional tour is focused on securing safe passage for those fleeing Afghanistan.

node.title: NZ police shoot man dead after stabbing incident
node.description: Videos online show panicked shoppers running out of the Countdown supermarket at LynnMall.

node.title: Armless swimmer Zheng Tao dominates the pool
node.description: The 30-year-old, who lost his arms from an electric shock, dominated the Games pool with four golds.

node.title: Japan's Suga to step down as prime minister
node.description: Mr Suga had been appointed to the role just a year ago following the resignation of Shinzo Abe.

node.title: China set to open new stock exchange in Beijing
node.description: The announcement comes as Chinese firms come under intense scrutiny both at home and in the US.

node.title: Fighting intensifies over holdout Afghan valley
node.description: The Panjshir Valley, near Kabul, is the only area of Afghanistan that has not fallen to the Taliban.

node.title: How to get half a million workers back to office
node.description: IT services giant TCS says it's ready to go back to the office after 18 months - how will that work?

node.title: The 9,000 child abuse cases filed decades late
node.description: Thousands of child sex abuse claims have been filed thanks to a change in New York law.

node.title: Storm Ida kills dozens across US north-east
node.description: President Biden calls for "historic investment" to tackle the climate crisis as the US reels from the storm.

node.title: How Europe soured on Joe Biden
node.description: In many EU circles, the honeymoon period for Donald Trump's successor may be coming to an end.

node.title: Islamic State 'Beatle' pleads guilty in US court
node.description: Alexanda Kotey is on trial for his involvement in the murders of US journalists and relief workers.

node.title: Panjshir - the valley trying to hold off the Taliban
node.description: The last bastion of resistance is still holding out just north-east of the capital, Kabul.

node.title: Climate-above-all plea by US fails to stir China
node.description: Envoy John Kerry's 'it's more important than politics' appeal falls on deaf ears.

node.title: China linked to takeover of Italian drone plant
node.description: Six people are reported to prosecutors over the takeover which police say broke arms laws.

node.title: Biden launches fight against Texas abortion ban
node.description: The president called the decision to allow the law to take effect an "unprecedented assault" on women's rights.

node.title: Fear for Hazara cousin's life in Afghanistan
node.description: Mahnaz says her relative believes he will be persecuted by the Taliban over his ethnic background.

node.title: Millions at risk under Ethiopia aid blockade - UN
node.description: "The world's worst famine situation in decades" is brewing in the north of the country, the UN says.

node.title: Family trapped in Afghanistan appeals for help
node.description: The Bradford family were visiting a relative when they were caught up in the Taliban takeover.

node.title: GM to idle North American plants amid chip shortage
node.description: Output will halt at eight plants in the US, Mexico and Canada amid a global shortage of semi-conductors.

node.title: The implications of Supreme Court’s abortion ruling
node.description: The court's refusal to block a Texas law that bans abortions for most women will be felt across the US.

node.title: China to rein in stars' pay in media crackdown
node.description: The regulator says it will shun actors with "effeminate" styles, punish tax evaders and limit reality shows.

node.title: Afghan boy who ate wild mushrooms dies in Poland
node.description: The five year old ate the mushrooms at a refugee centre near Warsaw after his evacuation from Kabul.

node.title: US states to accept driver's licence on iPhones
node.description: Apple's new ID system for its Wallet will be rolled out at airports to start.

node.title: Irish economy bounces back as restrictions ease
node.description: Figures from the Central Statistics Office show the Republic of Ireland's GDP increased by 6.3%.

node.title: Apple to allow Netflix-type apps a sign-up link
node.description: Apps offering books, videos or music will be able to offer a website link to sign up and manage accounts.

node.title: Farthing still working to rescue 'terrified' staff
node.description: The former Royal Marine who flew animals over from Afghanistan says he will not give up on staff.

node.title: TV host sentenced over rape re-enactment
node.description: A guest was asked to simulate a sexual assault using a mannequin live on Ivory Coast TV.

node.title: Landmine charity resumes work in Afghanistan
node.description: The Halo Trust, which has its HQ in Scotland, resumes its clearance operations under Taliban rule.

node.title: The man who fought for Kashmir’s freedom from India
node.description: Syed Ali Shah Geelani believed India should not rule the region and never changed his stand.

node.title: Zorba the Greek composer dies aged 96
node.description: Mikis Theodorakis was also a key figure of resistance to the Greek military junta of the 1970s.

node.title: The two countries throwing a lifeline to the Taliban
node.description: Qatar and Turkey emerge as key channels between Afghanistan's new rulers and the outside world.

node.title: Derry-based Afghan man's sister 'taken' in Kabul
node.description: Muhammad Edrees Kharotai wanted to get his family out of Afghanistan and bring them to Northern Ireland.

node.title: India actor Siddharth Shukla dies at 40
node.description: He acted in several hit TV shows and also won popular reality show Bigg Boss in 2019.

node.title: Raab in Qatar for talks on Afghan evacuations
node.description: The prospect of persuading the Taliban to reopen Kabul airport will be among the issues discussed.

node.title: Biden vows to defend abortion rights
node.description: The US president reacts after Texas adopts an "extreme" law banning abortion from six weeks.

node.title: Anger after Paralympian is stripped of gold medal
node.description: Muhammad Ziyad Zolkefli won his shot put event but had his title revoked because he was three minutes late.

node.title: Facebook says it helped people escape Afghanistan
node.description: The flight arrived in Mexico City on Wednesday, with 175 Afghan citizens on board, including 75 children.

node.title: Popular podcast host Joe Rogan says he has Covid
node.description: He caused controversy in April when he suggested young, healthy people did not need the vaccine.

node.title: Lynching blame game exposes Algerian elite's fears
node.description: Algerians are clamouring for democratic reforms and the weakening the influence of the military.

node.title: China steps in amid anger over brutal work hours
node.description: Workers in China are fed up with the brutal 12-hour work days once seen as a key driver of success.

node.title: Kabul make-up artist: 'Women like me are Taliban targets'
node.description: A make-up artist in hiding explains how much Afghanistan's beauty industry has meant to women.

node.title: Beaten and humiliated for being a Muslim in India
node.description: Attacks on Muslims by Hindu mobs have soared in India, with little apparent official condemnation.

node.title: Historic impeachment trial for Danish ex-minister
node.description: Inger Stoejberg is accused of unlawfully ordering the separation of young asylum-seeking couples.

node.title: Sacklers win immunity from further opioid litigation
node.description: A US judge has approved a bankruptcy plan for the maker of OxyContin painkillers.

node.title: Mr Zelensky (finally) goes to Washington
node.description: The Ukrainian president pressed by Donald Trump gets his White House visit - and a new set of worries.

node.title: Kashmir's separatist patriarch Geelani dies at 92
node.description: Veteran separatist leader Syed Ali Geelani, a staunch critic of India, had been under house arrest.

node.title: Taliban are ruthless, top US general says
node.description: General Mark Milley says it "remains to be seen" whether the Islamist group will change.

node.title: 'Covered in bruises, head to foot'
node.description: Middlesbrough MP Andy McDonald says his office is trying to help constituents to leave Afghanistan.

node.title: US: McDonald’s hiring 14 year-olds amid shortage
node.description: The Medford branch sees flood of applications after failing to recruit older workers.

node.title: Police and medics charged over black man's death
node.description: Elijah McClain, 23, was put in a chokehold and injected with ketamine after being stopped by police.

node.title: Biden on Afghanistan withdrawal fact-checked
node.description: How consistent is President Biden in his comments on Afghanistan following the final US troop withdrawal?

node.title: Passport delay blamed for baby stranded in Kabul
node.description: "We want to hug her, kiss her", say her parents, who had to return to the UK to replace travel documents.

node.title: Portugal changes vaccine rules for UK visitors
node.description: UK visitors no longer need to quarantine for 14 days if they can't prove they are fully vaccinated.

node.title: Is a majority within reach for Canada's Trudeau?
node.description: Midway into the general election, Trudeau's Liberals are struggling to gain traction with voters.

node.title: North Korea rejects offer of Chinese Covid-19 jabs
node.description: The country asked that the shots offered under the Covax scheme be redirected to harder hit nations.

node.title: French police crash after officer fires Taser
node.description: A lawyers says the officers were "having fun" when one fired her Taser and the driver lost control.

node.title: Unknown number left behind in Afghanistan - Raab
node.description: Dominic Raab believes the majority of eligible people have been evacuated to the UK - but cannot be precise.

node.title: Rescued Afghanistan animals in amazing condition
node.description: Most of the 150 dogs and cats rescued by "Pen" Farthing's charity are to be adopted by services personnel.

node.title: Afghan refugees' hopes for 'brighter future'
node.description: Afghan interpreters working for the British forces hope for a "brighter future" in the UK.

node.title: Zambia's new leader shocked by scale of corruption
node.description: Illicit funds are still being moved, Hakainde Hichilema tells the BBC, a week after he was sworn in.

node.title: Space station facing irreparable failures - Russia
node.description: The majority of in-flight systems on the ISS have passed their expiry date, an official warns.

node.title: Police alert as Italian trains require Covid pass
node.description: Anti-vaccination protesters say they will target rail services in more than 50 cities.

node.title: Iceland PM saddened by football sex abuse scandal
node.description: The board of Iceland's football authority resigned after it was accused of covering up allegations.

node.title: Drought hits South America's second-longest river
node.description: The Paraná is a key waterway for shipping and also provides drinking water for millions of people.

node.title: Will Smith reveals new Fresh Prince of Bel-Air
node.description: Newcomer Jabari Banks will take on the role in the upcoming NBC Peacock reboot of the hit 199s show.

node.title: Man arrested on suspicion of abducting toddler
node.description: The two-year-old girl was allegedly abducted from Lancaster and flown to Spain on 25 August.

node.title: Jamie Spears 'dragging feet' on Britney censorship
node.description: The pop star's father has been accused of trying to extort his daughter before departing the role.

node.title: 'Pollution may shorten life in India by nine years'
node.description: Millions in north India face the most extreme levels of air pollution in the world, the report says.

node.title: Couple divided by Irish border due to Brexit rules
node.description: Corrinne and Brett Giles live on either side of the Irish border due to post-Brexit immigration rules.

node.title: Tánaiste in NI for business and political talks
node.description: The Northern Ireland Protocol, Covid recovery and Troubles-related prosecutions are on the agenda.

node.title: Six-week abortion law comes into effect in Texas
node.description: The law, one of the most restrictive in the US, passes as the Supreme Court fails to block it.

node.title: British journalist killed in Ghana robbery
node.description: The 31-year-old from Hartlepool was making a documentary in Africa for a Muslim television network.

node.title: Sri Lanka in economic emergency as food prices soar
node.description: The government says it will seize food stocks and set prices to contain inflation.

node.title: Tongan royal family denies Australia murder link
node.description: It has addressed tabloid allegations that the king was involved in covering up a 1980s killing.

node.title: Japan finds black particles in Moderna vaccine
node.description: It comes less than a week after the country suspended more than a million doses due to contamination.

node.title: India sees record economic growth during Covid surge
node.description: The country suffered a devastating Covid spike in April and May but looser pandemic curbs still drove growth.

node.title: Afghans who worked for UK can stay permanently
node.description: Evacuees who worked for the British military and UK government will be given indefinite leave to remain.

node.title: Image of bird at US-Mexico border wall wins contest
node.description: The winning image by Mexican photographer Alejandro Prieto shows a roadrunner at the border wall.

node.title: The mystery fever that's killed dozens of children
node.description: At least 50 people, most of them children, have died in a week, and Indian officials don't know why.

node.title: Children fall victim to vicious French drug war
node.description: A 14-year-old is the latest victim of Marseille's gang war, prompting a key visit from President Macron.

node.title: US hate crime reports hit 12-year high in 2020
node.description: According to an FBI report, black and Asian Americans saw the biggest surges in targeted offences.

node.title: UK told Afghans to go to Abbey Gate before attack
node.description: Despite an attack being expected, emails seen by the BBC show embassy staff directing Afghans to the gate.

node.title: Biden defends Afghan exit amid Taliban joy
node.description: Staying in Afghanistan was not an option, the US president says, as Taliban militants celebrate.

node.title: UK and Taliban in talks over further evacuations
node.description: A UK official is in Qatar for talks to secure the exit of both UK and Afghan nationals, No 10 says.

node.title: Reprisals cast doubts over the Taliban's amnesty
node.description: Reports suggest the Taliban are searching for, and allegedly killing, people they pledged to leave in peace.

node.title: How can the West stop Afghan terror bases?
node.description: The foreign secretary says the UK will fight ISIS by all means available - but what does that mean?

node.title: British man trapped in Afghanistan pleads for help
node.description: The Liverpool taxi driver travelled to the country about two weeks ago to help his family flee.

node.title: Irish Cabinet agrees to ease most Covid-19 rules
node.description: Ministers met on Tuesday to agree on a plan to ease most Covid-19 restrictions by 22 October.

node.title: Irish population tops 5m for first time since 1851
node.description: There were also 742,300 people living in the Republic Ireland aged 65 and over in April, figures show.

node.title: Former interpreter fears for Afghan dad's safety
node.description: Now based in Coventry after assisting Army forces, he says his father is at risk amid Taliban control.

node.title: What is E10 petrol and can my car run it?
node.description: A more eco-friendly petrol is coming to filling stations in the UK - but it's not suitable for all cars.

node.title: Tribute paid to taxi driver killed in Kabul attack
node.description: Mohammad Niazi, from Hampshire, died alongside his wife and three-month-old daughter.

node.title: Sarah Rainsford: My last despatch before Russian expulsion
node.description: The BBC's Moscow correspondent has spent much of her life reporting in Russia. This is her final report.

node.title: Oil slick from Syria spreads across Mediterranean
node.description: Modelling suggests fuel that leaked from a power plant last week will soon reach northern Cyprus.

node.title: 'If you let go, I'll shoot you in the face.'
node.description: Brazil hostages describe terrifying ordeal as bank robbers used them as human shields on getaway cars.

node.title: Doctor fears for family's future in Afghanistan
node.description: Dr Waheed, who lives Chester, says his father and seven sisters are still living in Kabul.

node.title: Berlin's university canteens go almost meat-free
node.description: The new menus are designed to reduce the carbon footprint of universities in the German capital.

node.title: R. Kelly's first male accuser testifies to abuse
node.description: An unnamed man says the star promised fame in exchange for sex, while a female witness alleges rape.

node.title: Covid threatens Singapore's business hub crown
node.description: The South East Asian country faces opposing pressures over the large number of workers from overseas.
